column2: I understand that contributed datasets will be made available under a CC-BY or similar license. This means that the COSORE database will be open without restriction to the science community; we strongly encourage database users to cite original publications and offer co-authorship, but it's not required.
column3: I have all necessary authority and permissions (legal or otherwise) to provide these data to the COSORE database.
column4: Once we've worked through the metadata below, we'll send you a custom data upload link.
column5: COSORE is a community database, but not an institutionally-backed repository like Figshare, DataONE, ESS-DIVE, etc. We recommend depositing your data in one of these first, and providing its DOI below.

column11: David Lipson; dlipson@sdsu.edu; funding aquisition, advising, investigation
column19: Coastal Sage Scrub (CSS) vegetation is dominated by the native shrubs Artemisia californica, Eriogonum fasciculatum and Salvia mellifera; intershrub spaces contain invasive annual grasses Bromus madritensis var. rubens and forbs Centaurea solstitialis and Hirschfeldia incana
column23: This data was originally collected and analysed by Marguerite Mauritz and David Lipson to investigate soil respiration patterns in semi-arid shrubland invaded by annual grasses and forbs. The LI-8100 was kindly loaned by Walt Oechel.

column38: Air temp, Soil temp, Soil moisture, PAR, Other
column40: Ports did not monitor the same plots/treatments continuously.

column11: Eric A. Davidson (0000-0002-8525-8697, edavidson@umces.edu, PI), Kathleen E. Savage (savage@whrc.org, data curator).
column19: The dominant tree species are red spruce (Picea rubens Sarg.) and eastern hemlock (Tsuga canadensis (L.) Carr.), with associated mixed hardwoods.
column22: Soil respiration data are made available along with the code used for the primary publication in this GitHub repository: https://github.com/trevorkeenan/FoBAAR-DAMM
column23: Those who intend to use the continuous soil respiration dataset from the Howland forest site for their research are strongly encouraged to contact and acknowledge the contributors listed above.

column40:
Two things to consider: 
1. We have continuous data from 2004-2015 for six chambers. However, we have done the root trenching experiment during 2013â€“15 for three chambers.
2. David Hollinger (site PI) is the contact person for ancillary dataset (other than soil temperature and soil moisture). Should this be considered for the "contributor(s)" section?

column11: Eric A. Davidson (0000-0002-8525-8697, edavidson@umces.edu, PI), Kathleen E. Savage (savage@whrc.org, data curator)
column19: Stands in this forest consist primarily of red oak (Quercus rubra) and red maple (Acer rubrum).
column23: Those who intend to use the continuous soil respiration dataset from the Harvard forest site for their research are strongly encouraged to contact and acknowledge the contributors listed above.
column40:
We have automated data from the control (2012-2014) and root-trenched (2013-2014) chambers from US-Ha1 (EMS tower site). Additionally, we have automated chamber data from different stands withing Harvard forest for three more years (2003, 2009, and 2010) with different treatments (trenching, rainfall exclusion, root exudation etc) based on different research objectives in each study. 

We have soil temperature and soil moisture data for all chambers. Other ancillary data are generally available from the Harvard Forest LTER website.
